comments.commentBody: With 67% of the vote in, Vermont Public Radio now has the Dem, Peter Shumlin, up 51% to 46% (approx. 6,400 votes) over the GOP's Brian Dubie in the VT governor's race. Question is, where do the remaining 85 precincts come from & how many votes do they represent?

"On NBC, Brian Williams interviewed the often incendiary Republican representative Michele Bachmann, who challenged the view that it was largely a negative vote from the country, saying it was also a positive vote for fiscal responsibility. She argued that the top priority for the lame duck Congress would be to extend tax cuts for all income groups."  And that's fiscal responsibility?  Only 18% of even Tea Party people think that cutting taxes with this deficit is a good idea.  Bachmann is from another planet.

Someone should be watching the CNBC feed. Its the only US feed i can get here in Europe. It is a long parade of CEOs getting giddy about the prospect of less regulation and the gutting of regulatory agencies in a quest to bring down the deficit.

I know it is a financial network but they are really going for it with the results. At one point the more-left-leaning (not by much) co-anchor called the EPA the Employment Prevention Agency.

Later they showed an exit poll which had voters blaming Wall Street the most for the state of the economy (35%), Bush second (29%) and Obama third (24%), there was a moment of does not compute. After a brief pause the commentator asked when was the President going to change his rhetoric and stop blaming Wall Street.

It is surreal viewing.

Here's Christine O'Donnell's concession speech to cheer you up:
http://bit.ly/aOs7lg

I suppose the voters in Kentucky didn't care if Rand Paul worshiped Aqua Buddha in college. And even though Rand Paul couldn't bring himself to say that he would have voted for the 65 Civil Rights Act, lots of Obama voters were more comfortable voting for him than Jack Conway, a Democratic twit who campaigned for cannabis prohibition. Conway said we can't have industrial hemp because the drug warriors would have a hard time telling the difference between rope weed and the good stuff. Diane Feinstein and Obama, are you paying attention?
Michelle Bachmann looked and sounded like a Stepford Wife, so kudos to Chris Matthews for calling her out on that.  But what is with the folks in Minnesota who've elected this airhead?

I have only seen Michelle Bachmann interviewed a couple of times, but Matthews observation is exactly what I saw then. I couldn't believe how moronic and repetitive her answers were, mostly totally unrelated to the questions. I seriously wonder how on earth this woman has made it this far.

Very good idea, Keith.  You are increasingly an articulate, serious, compelling voice for progressives.  This segment, on the other hand, is juvenile, unnecessary, and reductive--and thus belongs more to the cynical, phony bobble-heads on Fox News.
ABC, home of George Stephanopoulos, is obviously terrified of opinions not vetted by their top execs.

Chris Matthews is always good for a laugh.  Bachmann deserved it though.  She shouldn't have agreed to do his show if she didn't want to answer the questions.  What was she thinking?  Was she thinking?

So, the American public "threw the bums out" ,what they do every time things don't go well. If any one thinks there will be a change, they are in for a rude awakening. We are still spending billions in Afghanistan. The "Tea Party" will be meeting their real masters - the Republican business class. And gridlock continues..... Don't complain America: most of you didn't vote!

Consider this for a moment: Maybe it was worth it. Obama is losing the house, and will have a more difficult time in the Senate, but perhaps it was worth it to get the Health Care Bill passed. Now, some may say the bill was not good enough, but it may also be the best we could have had, and it is already making a difference. It is said, perfect is the enemy of done, and that is certainly true here. At least one former Senator thought so, because Blanche Lincoln voted yes to the bill, perhaps knowing she would not be re-elected as a result.
I think the reason more folks have turned against Obama is because they simply do not understand the forces, fortunes, stacked against him. They do not understand what he has already done for them.

Luckily, we should see a lot of strength among Congressional Republicans because of the success of the Tea Party Movement in electing its candidates in Republican primary races.  I was okay with the government shut down in the Clinton era.  As a taxpayer, I'm tired of funding other people's mistakes...

With the Republican successes comes a continuing disaster for America. There will again be good things happening for the 2% richest of America and Big Oil and Big Pharma and mega corporations based in foreign lands. The rest of America will find that Halloween this year is going to last a long, long, long time.

It seems to me that only recalcitrant old voters actually voted "en masse" today. I did not see any young people voting, only people in their late forties all the way to the eighties. I would like to know what percentage of registered voters actually voted.

The White House has failed to retain the loyalties of its base. Obama & Co. had a touching faith in the ability of governments to deliver on 'shovel ready' projects.

If those stimulus funds had gone into middle class tax cuts and larger earned income credits, it would be the Republicans who were licking their wounds today.

The fact that the Democrats have done poorly in the elections is their own fault. The Democratic Party was weak.

What did Obama expect after letting Wall Street looters receive bonuses that average $600,000 annually while everyone else is feeling the pain? I am not referring to TARP, which was enacted while Bush 43 was president. When Obama took office, he should have fired all the top management at every firm that needed to bailed out by the taxpayer. My tax dollars bailed out these crooks who still received astronomical bonuses and what did I or anyone else for it but the bill?

Although I am angry with the Democrats, I am disappointed that they have done well in the mid-terms. They passed some reforms that I felt were moving the country in the right direction. The extremism of the Republicans will drive this country completely off the cliff.

It is not Obama who created the deficits or the debt. The debt load the U.S. carries is due to Reagan, Bush 41 and Bush 43? How could any reasonable person expect the Democrats to come close to a balanced budget after George W. Bush's disastrous presidency? It was impossible.

I have no hope that this country will ever get back on track. Both parties are infested with corporate money, which actually runs the show. However, to elect extreme Republicans will only give us as bad or worse than Bush 43. The American electorate never ceases to amaze me.

I wonder how many will be sorry if Social Security is privatized or Medicare disappears.

I am Independent who voted for the Democrats. I could never have voted for the extremism of the Republicans. I predict that the next two years will be a mess.

Stimulus? Not undersold, but completely worthless poolicy, well worth rejecting the authors of. Every dollar spent at point A was taxed or borrowed or printed from point B, so every positive stimulus at A was matched by a negative stimulus at B. Worthless. And the failure of President Bush's huge deficits and stimuli/bailouts to do any good should've warned President Obama about this; likewise FDR's failure to dent the great depression. Well, now he know it from his own experience. So do the voters.

Health care (insurance, really), by telling us to buy it? By telling insurance companies they have to pay for this, that, and the other? No wonder they're already raising prices. And why aren't we already getting tax-paid health as good as Canada or Britain, if US health spending paid by taxpayers is the same GDP percentage as theirs? Do the old and new bureaucrats in D.C. know as much about my health, and about my wallet, as I? You want to cut health costs, let consumers of health care keep some of what we save when we cut health spending! Again, our President's problem is his policies, not his salesmanship.

Jesus Christ is rather libertarian. He's a very practical guy.
www.lohr84.com

The Party of No will now have to pretend to govern.  This should be interesting.  Exactly how do they expect to convince their colleagues that the program of obfuscation, outright lies and obstinacy that delivered the election results should be rewarded with cooperation?

I'm a Democrat and Obama supporter who sees good in tonight's election results.  First of all, this should put an end to the in-fighting inside the Obama Administration since certain people in his administration have been discredited by the Republican smack down the same way Dick Channey and Donald Rumsfeld were discredited after the '06 capture of the House and Senate by the Democrats.  After '06, with Channey's influence diminished and Rumsfeld gone, The Bush Administration began to refocus its Iraq War policy which lead to the Surge and the eventual conditions for the US to began a draw down.  I hope this happens with the Obama administration.  Those in his administration advising against focusing on jobs and the economy should now be in the same place as those who advised Bush the Iraqis would meet the US with open arms and gratitude.

I am so glad I now live in Massachusetts. Democrats here won EVERY OFFICE. Apparently, the surprise GOP win by Scott Brown earlier this year (in a special election for the late Sen Kennedy) had no coat-tails.

Democrats nationwide would do well to learn from the incredible campaign that was run by Deval Patrick, our re-elected Democrat incumbent black governor who is friends with President Obama -- and listen several times to Patrick's celebration acceptance speech. It was perfect in tone and he hit all the right notes just as he did in his campaign. (Local pundits said he was "dead in the water" as recently as April of this year.)

The Republicans stumbled around this state -- and lost every race.

American voters are concerned and worried about what is happening to our economy. For the first time, Americans are not confident that their children will live a better life and have more opportunities than they did. And the voters struck out at the majority party, the Democrats.

The economy is not going to improve during the next two years, so the voters will express their anger again by trying to bring about more change in the political status quo in 2012.

The economy will not improve until we bring thousands of factories and millions of jobs back from China. And then the voters will be satisfied as our economy returns to prosperity, and their children's future will be bright once again.

Frank Mitchell
jobsback.com

So - Patty Murray's looking pretty good in Washington and assuming Colorado & Nevada go Democrat, that should pretty much give Dems a majority . . . right?  Do they need BOTH Colorado & Nevada or just 1 of them . . . I've lost track. I'm still interested to see what happens in Alaska; if Lisa M pulls it out the Tea Party's not gonna be looking too hot.

Days like today make me proud to be a CT resident. CT may be boring, but at least we're not crazy. And we don't fall for people who claim to be fiscally conservative whilst pouring $40+ million into a campaign (in a state with the biggest gap between rich and poor this is just shameful).

Now if only we could vote out Lieberman...
This just in from the RNC: Deficits don't matter.
